body: I can train yolov4.cfg in 2 RTX 2080Ti with batch size = 10. however, I have to train from scratch because the yolov3-spp-ultralytich.pt is not compatible with yolov4.cfg. Till now, I see accuracy of yolov4 is quite bad with my dataset compared to yolov3 ... maybe caused by training from scratch ?

rename.from: the Mish activation is not cuda memory friendly

body:
@Libaishun @anhnktp I did a quick training test on our colab notebook. Yes it seems your results are correct, yolov4.cfg is using up **1.65X the amount of GPU memory** as yolov3-spp.cfg.

```
python train.py --data coco64.data --weights '' --img-size 640 --batch 8
```

- `--cfg yolov4.cfg` - 14.1G
- `--cfg yolov3-spp.cfg` - 8.5G

I and @thomasbrandon will be working on providing most optimal memory friendly version of Mish. Mish CUDA is already a heavily optimized version available for use (https://github.com/thomasbrandon). To make it even more faster, use exponential equivalents of TanH. Furthermore you could write the backward pass with Swish as well: 
If f(x) = Mish then it's derivative could be written as: 
f'(x) = delta(x) * Swish (x) + f(x)/x 
Where delta(x) = sech^2(Softplus(x)) 
The delta(x) term could be further optimized with its exponential equivalents. 
We do have a closed issue where we had significant discussion on how to make Mish lighter: https://github.com/digantamisra98/Mish/issues/22
Additionally, we are also working on porting self normalizing properties of SeLU to Mish to avoid the need of Batch Norm layers.

@digantamisra98 hi there! In yolov4.cfg I see that @alexeyab made judicious use of the mish activation, using it only in the most important places, but it looks like in pytorch at least yolov4.cfg still increases the gpu ram requirements significantly, assuming the standard mish class. I looked at @thomasbrandon repo, but it looked like it required building CUDA from source with his extensions included, which may be a bridge too far for many users, especially those with short-lived environments like Google Colab notebooks. I was thinking perhaps you guys could look at lighter weight approximations, sort of the way the mobilenetv3 guys replaced swish with a 'hard-swish' which removed the sigmoid. At the end of the day the best implementation we want is probably a compromise between speed, memory and accuracy. https://arxiv.org/pdf/1905.02244.pdf

@digantamisra98 but I suppose since I have you here, what's your advice for the time being on the current mish implementation here? Do the JIT decorators (which I don't have) affect GPU operations or are they targeted to CPU operations?

https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/blob/692f945819a877917bfeaec447af75cc31025233/utils/layers.py#L121-L123

@glenn-jocher yes, hard mish is on the cards. Here was a short discussion on it on the Fast.ai forums - https://forums.fast.ai/t/hard-mish-activation-function/59238
But, it will take some time to validate h-mish both in terms of numerical stability and results from using it.
